conclusion: To determine the direction of wave propagation and the wave speed, we need to analyze the given figures and use the properties of waves.
From Figure 2, the time interval between two peaks is 4 seconds.
The time period \( T \) is the time for one complete cycle, so \( T = 4 \) seconds.
From Figure 1, the distance between \( x = 0 \) and \( x = 2 \) is 2 meters, and the next corresponding point is at \( x = 4 \) meters.
The wavelength \( \lambda \) is the distance between two corresponding points on adjacent waves, so \( \lambda = 4 \) meters.
The wave speed \( v \) is given by \( v = \frac{\lambda}{T} = \frac{4 \text{ m}}{4 \text{ s}} = 1 \text{ m/s} \).
From Figure 2, the particle at \( x = 2 \) meters is at its maximum displacement at \( t = 2 \) seconds.
The wave is moving to the right because if it were moving to the left, the particle at \( x = 2 \) meters would be at its minimum displacement at \( t = 2 \) seconds.
The direction of wave propagation is to the right, and the wave speed is \( 1 \text{ m/s} \).
